profileText: A Representative from Iowa; born in Denmark, Oxford County, Maine, September 2, 1827; attended the common schools and was graduated from North Bridgeton Academy; member of the State house of representatives from Penobscot County in 1855 and 1856; moved to Iowa, and settled in Osage, Mitchell County, in 1857; engaged in the lumber business and built and operated a sawmill; for several years a clerk in the United States Senate, but resigned in 1865; special agent of the Post Office Department for the district of Minnesota, Iowa, and Nebraska from 1865 to 1869, when he resigned; national-bank examiner for the State of Iowa 1872-1877; elected as a Republican to the Forty-fifth, Forty-sixth, and Forty-seventh Congresses (March 4, 1877-March 3, 1883); chairman, Committee on Expenditures in the Department of State (Forty-seventh Congress); unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1882; engaged in agricultural pursuits; also interested in cattle raising in Montana, and at the time of his death served as president of a large cattle company in that territory; died in Osage, Mitchell County, Iowa, December 11, 1887; interment in Osage Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In the John Milton Hay Papers, 1854-1914, approximately 6,000 items.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include Nathaniel Cobb Deering.

researchRecord.name: 1864, 1877-1883; 10 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence from Nathaniel Cobb Deering and a Mr. Bailey requesting 12 copies of the Congressional Globe, as well as letters to Benjamin Perley Poore concerning information in the Congressional Directory.

researchRecord.name: In the James Henry Deering Receipt Book and Miscellany, 1860-1887, 1 folder
researchRecord.description: The collections includes a letter (Sept. 19, 1887) to James Deering in San Francisco, Calif. from his brother, Nathaniel Cobb Deering, in Osage Iowa.
